pullrequest.title: Display joint type, parent link's name and child link's name on world tree

content.raw:
We should add a helper function to msgs.cc for this logic. I have actually implemented the reverse in a branch ( a1ee8f3 ):
~~~
msgs::Joint::Type Convert(const std::string &_str);
~~~

I would propose moving this switch statement to a new function:
~~~
std::string Convert(const msgs::Joint::Type _type);
~~~

I can help with this and writing a unit test if necessary.
content.html:
We should add a helper function to msgs.cc for this logic. I have actually implemented the reverse in a branch ( a1ee8f3 ):

msgs::Joint::Type Convert(const std::string &_str);

I would propose moving this switch statement to a new function:

std::string Convert(const msgs::Joint::Type _type);

I can help with this and writing a unit test if necessary.

pullrequest.title: Display joint type, parent link's name and child link's name on world tree

content.html:
For the test, would something like this be enough?

TEST_F(MsgsTest, ConvertMsgsJointTypeToString)
{
  std::string str = msgs::Convert(msgs::Joint::REVOLUTE);

  EXPECT_STREQ("revolute", str.c_str());
}

pullrequest.title: Display joint type, parent link's name and child link's name on world tree

content.html:
We could test the pair of functions together:

msgs::Joint::Type type = msgs::Joint::REVOLUTE;
EXPECT_EQ(type, msgs::Convert(msgs::Convert(type)));

content.raw: I used `else if`s because I was checking strings, and I wasn't sure that `switch` works well with strings. I would defer to @nkoenig or @iche033 for their opinion.

content.raw: technically the `parent` and `child` fields are optional, so we should check `has_parent()` and `has_child()` before calling `child()` or `parent()`
content.html: technically the parent and child fields are optional, so we should check has_parent() and has_child() before calling child() or parent()
